Evidently of the opinion that the
prisoners have been coddled long
enough, Hopkins graduate'students
have begun teaching at the Marylad Penitentiary. The inmates,
who, it would seem, believe in a
literal interpretation of the motto,
"Veritas vos liberabit," have been
attending these classes with surprising regularity.
Almost any evening now will find
an eager group of students arrayed
before a blackboard in the assembly
room, scrawling elephantine letters,
or reading from a primer, while
who knows but a gentleman from
Chicago may be aiming a rubber
band at an inoffensive fly on
teacher's nose. As a general rule,
though, the potential "A. B.'s in
Carcera" are extremely interested
in their education, in spite of the
fact that R. 0. T. C. target practice
is arbitrarily omitted.
"I See the Cat"
In some of the classes the pupils
have received so little previous education that instruction must start at
the very beginning. In these groups,
the general procedure is to have the
class read the degree letters after
the instructor's -fiai-ne. In cases
where this has proven too difficult
and involved, poetry by Gertrude
Stein has been substituted.
At a more advanced stage, however, the pedagogue may be seen to
write a sentence on the blackboard
and then admonish his class in the
very sternest of tones, "I see the
cat." Whereupon a lusty chorus of
some fifteen or twenty voices,raised
as if in a hallalujah reiterates, "I
see the cat." If the general opinion
is that everyone has seen the cat,
all is well.

Editor of NEWS-LETTER
Dear Sir:
Please don't make me lose my
job quicker than I am likely to do
anyhow! In your issue of today,
in a report of my remarks in the
Student Assembly, you quote me as
saying: "The worst minds, if any
at all, are at the head of this University. It's a mighty poor college."
I did not say this. I tried to make
the point that the authorities of the
University may profit by an alert
student opinion. So far from saying that we have a mighty poor
college, I said that I think it is now
a mighty good one. I said that last
session it was poor, but that by refusing to be indifferent to its condition we have greatly improved it.
BROADUS MITCHELL.
Nov. 21, 1930.

Men of note in the scientific
world will be brought to the Johns
Hopkins University during 193031, under the auspices of the
Dohme Foundation, to address the
21 Fellows and the faculty in the
University's department of chemistry. Dr. Arthur D. Little, of
Boston, who spoke at the recent
National Fellowship Plan conference at Homewood, presented the
first lecture in the series of eight
to be given here.
The other speakers will include
Dr. Eric Rideal, Cambridge, England; Dr. J. J. Abel, of the Johns
Hopkins School of Medicine; Dr.
Marston T. Bogart, Columbia University; Prof. K. Freudenberg, of
Heidelberg, Germany; Dr. William
Crocker, Boyce Thompson Institute, Yonkers, N. Y.; Dr. Moses
Gomber, University of Michigan;
Dr. Charles A. Kraus, Brown University; Dr. Wilder D. Bancroft,
Cornell University.
The lectures are presented in
order to permit the Fellows on the
campus to become acquainted with
well-known scientists.

Evidently of the opinion that the
prisoners have been coddled long
enough, Hopkins graduate'students
have begun teaching at the Marylad Penitentiary. The inmates,
who, it would seem, believe in a
literal interpretation of the motto,
"Veritas vos liberabit," have been
attending these classes with surprising regularity.
Almost any evening now will find
an eager group of students arrayed
before a blackboard in the assembly
room, scrawling elephantine letters,
or reading from a primer, while
who knows but a gentleman from
Chicago may be aiming a rubber
band at an inoffensive fly on
teacher's nose. As a general rule,
though, the potential "A. B.'s in
Carcera" are extremely interested
in their education, in spite of the
fact that R. 0. T. C. target practice
is arbitrarily omitted.
"I See the Cat"
In some of the classes the pupils
have received so little previous education that instruction must start at
the very beginning. In these groups,
the general procedure is to have the
class read the degree letters after
the instructor's -fiai-ne. In cases
where this has proven too difficult
and involved, poetry by Gertrude
Stein has been substituted.
At a more advanced stage, however, the pedagogue may be seen to
write a sentence on the blackboard
and then admonish his class in the
very sternest of tones, "I see the
cat." Whereupon a lusty chorus of
some fifteen or twenty voices,raised
as if in a hallalujah reiterates, "I
see the cat." If the general opinion
is that everyone has seen the cat,
all is well.

Editor of NEWS-LETTER
Dear Sir:
Please don't make me lose my
job quicker than I am likely to do
anyhow! In your issue of today,
in a report of my remarks in the
Student Assembly, you quote me as
saying: "The worst minds, if any
at all, are at the head of this University. It's a mighty poor college."
I did not say this. I tried to make
the point that the authorities of the
University may profit by an alert
student opinion. So far from saying that we have a mighty poor
college, I said that I think it is now
a mighty good one. I said that last
session it was poor, but that by refusing to be indifferent to its condition we have greatly improved it.
BROADUS MITCHELL.
Nov. 21, 1930.

John Herman Randall, director
of the World Unity Foundation,
will be at the University Thursday,
December 4, when he will speak at
assembly and a faculty luncheon
immediately after.
Dr. Randall is a well-known
Baptist minister, and is at present
greatly interested in the union of
the Christian churches throughout
the world.

Men of note in the scientific
world will be brought to the Johns
Hopkins University during 193031, under the auspices of the
Dohme Foundation, to address the
21 Fellows and the faculty in the
University's department of chemistry. Dr. Arthur D. Little, of
Boston, who spoke at the recent
National Fellowship Plan conference at Homewood, presented the
first lecture in the series of eight
to be given here.
The other speakers will include
Dr. Eric Rideal, Cambridge, England; Dr. J. J. Abel, of the Johns
Hopkins School of Medicine; Dr.
Marston T. Bogart, Columbia University; Prof. K. Freudenberg, of
Heidelberg, Germany; Dr. William
Crocker, Boyce Thompson Institute, Yonkers, N. Y.; Dr. Moses
Gomber, University of Michigan;
Dr. Charles A. Kraus, Brown University; Dr. Wilder D. Bancroft,
Cornell University.
The lectures are presented in
order to permit the Fellows on the
campus to become acquainted with
well-known scientists.
